newsitem.title: UK: Sumitomo Corp may have more copper to sell.
newsitem.headline: Sumitomo Corp may have more copper to sell.

text.p: Sumitomo Corp may not have liquidated all its long positions on the world copper markets, and may have "several hundred thousand tonnes to liquidate", Herbert Black, president of American Iron and Metal Co Inc said.
Black said at a American Metal Market luncheon that the copper price may spike upwards in the very short term to $2,000/$2,100 a tonne, but it will trade down to $1,600 next year and $1,400 in 1998.
Montreal-based scrap trader Black is widely believed to be among those who broke Sumitomo's control of the copper market, which their former trader Yasuo Hamanaka exerted for many years.
"Sumitomo was the force behind the market...but he (Hamanaka) did not realise how big the funds were. Sumitomo was accustomed to taking on small players, not big funds," he said.
Black said that although Sumitomo has already upwardly revised its losses in unauthorised trading from an initial $1.8 billion to $2.6 billion, they may be even higher.
"I feel confident the position (Sumitomo's) has not been unwound." --London Newsroom +44 171 542 8057
